newsitem.title: FRANCE: TENNIS-BEATEN HINGIS PUTS ON BRAVE FACE.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-BEATEN HINGIS PUTS ON BRAVE FACE.

text.p: Martina Hingis showed at the French Open on Saturday that she does not only know how to win -- she also knows how to lose.

The 16-year-old Swiss, who has sometimes shown a propensity to pout and throw her racquet when matches have not gone her way, accepted her defeat to Iva Majoli with a smile and the grace of a champion.

"If you lose a Grand Slam final you don't feel very happy but Iva was just the better player today," said Hingis, her trademark smile never leaving her face. "I don't mind losing to her because we're very good friends.
"It's no problem for me, I've had a great year so far. For sure it's frustrating to lose in the final but my career doesn't end right now."

The world number one, however, will take some extra time off to rest the knee she injured when she fell off a horse in April. The injury sidelined the teenager for the five weeks leading up to the start of the French Open.
Hingis said she would now resist the urge to play in the grass court tune-up tournaments ahead of Wimbledon, returning instead to her home outside Zurich.

"I don't feel like I want to play another tournament next week," said Hingis, who became the youngest ever Wimbledon champion last year when she teamed up with Helena Sukova to win the doubles title. "The knee is not 100 percent yet, I'm going to take it a little easier.
"No one can appreciate what it took to compete at this tournament. No one sees what hard work it was to get here after the surgery.
"I don't want to be tired for Wimbledon. I've played enough tennis for a while."
Hingis, under the guidance of her mother and coach Melanie, appears willing to pace herself and take advice.
"You can always learn from losing," said Hingis, who hasn't had too many lessons this season having strung together 37 consecutive victories before her loss to Majoli.
